Secondly, any agreement must take into account the serious reservations expressed this week by the US Arms Control Association, which stated that there is no way Australia can guarantee that our uranium, when sold to China, will not be used for illegal nuclear weapons. Along with this essential component of any Australia-China agreement is the urgent need for renewed efforts towards nuclear disarmament worldwide. The tragic history of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, the worrying developments in Iran and the failure of the recent NPT meetings are the clear signs on this issue.

Little has been heard recently in relation to the government’s involvement in the seven-nations initiative, which is sponsored by Norway and includes the United Kingdom and South Africa and which is aimed to address, as UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan said, ‘challenges to the nuclear non-proliferation regime’. We watch this initiative with great interest. In fact, we cautiously welcome it, as it does include a reference to the comprehensive test ban treaty and to nuclear weapons-free zones, but the initiative has, on first reading, a number of deficiencies. There is no reference to the de-alerting of nuclear weapons, an essential first step in reducing tension, little emphasis on disarmament and renewed emphasis on reasserting the inalienable right of states to peaceful uses of nuclear energy. The safeguards regime in relation to so-called ‘peaceful use’ to date has experienced failure. In the future, with the prospects of increased uranium sales to countries such as China, these failures, if they continue, could prove fatal, particularly in the event of interception by terrorists.

If we are not resolute in addressing disarmament, de-alerting nuclear weapons and ensuring that the safeguards regime is watertight—and I express my concern about the possibility of the government not doing that—then our inalienable rights to live in a secure and safe environment, which are a legacy of the terrible experiences of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, remind us of the need for the government to do more in relation to this. I urge the government to press strongly for the following measure to be agreed on during the 14 to 16 September summit of world leaders: committing themselves to the achievement of a total and unequivocal elimination of all nuclear arsenals as agreed during the 2000 non-proliferation treaty review conference. This is the task that faces the government. It is an urgent task. We look forward to their action.

talk.start.para: —Bundaberg may be famous for its sugar cane and rum but the city is also home to a quiet revolution in industrial diversification. In recent years I have told the House about an amazing range of new industries which call Bundaberg home—everything from light aviation manufacturing and the establishment of a major call centre through to the processing of small crops and the development of scallop ranching. This week I will be launching Bundaberg’s Austrade export hub, which can only enhance the innovation already taking place in the region. During the last year the federal government has committed to establishing eight regional export hubs to help companies in regional Australia develop their competition advantage and maximise their potential.

speech.para: The Bundaberg Export Hub will bring together the services of AusIndustry and TradeStart, meaning that our local businesses can access both agencies in a single location. The hub will help businesses which want to crack the export market. Our exporters compete with the world’s best companies. They innovate, they create, and they bring their technology, skills and know-how back for the benefit of their local economy. One company which can attest to the value of AusIndustry’s assistance is Microair Avionics Pty Ltd, which produces a range of avionic products, including radios, transponders and altitude encoders—right in Bundaberg. Microair has used AusIndustry’s R&D Start grants—now known as Commercial Ready—to develop new technologies. With the help of TradeStart and Austrade, the company now exports on a regular basis to 36 countries, including the US, a market which accounts for 45 per cent of total sales.

Austchilli is another success story, having cracked the export market seven years ago. Austchilli produces a range of more than 30 pureed products for the food manufacturing sector and otherwise exports to 14 countries in Asia, the Middle East and Europe. The company attributes much of its success to the support provided by Bundaberg’s TradeStart office and through Austrade’s Export Market Development Grants Scheme. Exporting its products means the company has been able to grow significantly. It recently moved into a new facility which is three times larger than its previous one. It employs a permanent staff of 40 people, swelling to more than 100 at seasonal peaks.

Bundaberg Brewed Drinks—a dynamic Bundaberg based business which the Minister for Trade and Deputy Prime Minister, Mark Vaile, visited recently—has also met with tremendous success, thanks to government support. In 1992, exports from Bundaberg Brewed Drinks represented only 20 per cent of their business but, by 2003, exports represented 30 per cent of their business. Chairman Cliff Fleming has credited the government’s Export Market Development Grants Scheme as giving the business the confidence to go overseas and look for new opportunities. He has been exporting to New Zealand for 19 years.

The other major centre in my electorate—Gladstone—is also home to a new AusIndustry office in recognition of its potential in terms of new export businesses. Ian McKirdy, AusIndustry’s regional manager, has recently had discussions with more than 100 businesses in Gladstone, and many are eager to take advantage of the 30 business assistance programs now available through AusIndustry.

Regional areas have a particularly important role to play in expanding exports, with exporter numbers growing at three times the rate of that in metropolitan areas. So getting the right mix of direct business development and export support is particularly important to regional centres such as Bundaberg and Gladstone. Last financial year, 61 Wide Bay—encompassing the Hinkler and Wide Bay electorates—businesses achieved export success through the TradeStart program, with 34 of them entering the new export game. That is a truly significant achievement. The flow-on benefits can be seen throughout the region. I thank the Deputy Prime Minister for his visit to Bundaberg. With trade it is very important to have not only ministerial visits to the country but also the human face of the department in the country so that exporters can get appropriate advice, receive market development grants and expand their businesses. This is certainly the case in Bundaberg and Gladstone.

talk.start.para: —A year ago this week, the majority of shops at the Orange Grove designer outlet centre in Liverpool closed their doors. Over 400 jobs were lost and businesses shut down. The closure was the subject of an inquiry by the New South Wales upper house and an inquiry by the Independent Commission Against Corruption. Those inquiries have run their course and, while no findings of corrupt conduct have been made, not everyone has come away smelling of roses.

speech.para: The ICAC inquiry looked to establish whether any corrupt conduct had occurred in relation to the decision by Liverpool City Council to grant a development consent to Gazcorp for the use of the Orange Grove premises as a warehouse clearance outlet, and in relation to the refusal by the Minister Assisting the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning to make Liverpool local environment plan amendment No. 92 to permit the premises to continue to operate as a retail outlet centre.

In relation to the first of those matters, the ICAC found that the Liverpool City Council approval was not as a result of any corrupt conduct or improper influence. This left the ICAC to decide whether unfounded allegations of corruption or improper conduct passed from Gazcorp’s competitor Westfield to Graeme Wedderburn, the chief of staff of the Premier, and through him passed on to and influenced the minister, Diane Beamer. In its report, the commission found that the allegations by Westfield’s director, Mark Ryan, were:

quote.para: ... at best indifferent, possibly misguided and at worst mischievous ...

speech.para: But, in spite of a swag of evidence, the commission said it could not substantiate claims that the corruption allegations made by Mr Ryan adversely affected Minister Beamer’s decision. The ICAC described the so-called web of influence chart presented by Ryan, saying:

quote.para: It contained errors and was patently designed to inform dissemination of his ill-founded prejudice.

speech.para: These discredited claims were the basis of Westfield’s approach to the Premier’s chief of staff and were raised at a meeting between Mr Wedderburn and Mr Carr. The ICAC report notes:

quote.para: Mr Carr and Mr Wedderburn had had no particular or relevant foreshadowing from any source about Orange Grove but Mr Ryan’s tantalising references were well and truly picked up by their political antennas.

speech.para: The report concludes that:

quote.para: ... without Mr Ryan’s approach to Mr Wedderburn, Mr Wedderburn would have done nothing at all.

speech.para: But Mr Wedderburn did not do nothing. For a start, he conveyed concerns to the office of Minister Beamer. The report states:

quote.para: ... she was being counselled by the Premier’s Chief of Staff to stick to the rules ...

speech.para: That was not the only action taken by Mr Wedderburn. He met with Jennifer Westacott, the department head. The department’s corporate counsel told the ICAC:

quote.para: Ms Westacott had mentioned to him that Mr Wedderburn had been urging her to be careful with the Orange Grove matter.

speech.para: In dealing with the department’s planning advice to approve the application and allow the centre to remain open, Ms Westacott was described as a harsh critic of the report’s conclusions. Others present at the time described her as ‘strident’, with another saying he had never seen a performance like it.

Knowing full well that her decision would result in the loss of over 400 jobs, the minister, against the advice of planning staff and on the advice of her department head, refused the application. There was an awful lot of smoke, but the ICAC says it could not find the fire. However, the ICAC’s recommendations point to the real problems in this case. These include amending the ministerial code of conduct to include guidelines about lobbying activities and a protocol for managing allegations of corrupt conduct made against external parties. If these had been in place at the time, they would have been clearly breached and there would have been significant consequences for those involved. But that is no consolation for over 400 workers who lost their jobs at Orange Grove.

talk.start.para: —In the days and weeks leading up to the swearing-in of the new Senate, Australians were subjected to illogical, hysterical and laughable claims by critics and some commentators that the Howard government was somehow no longer democratically accountable to the public. The alleged reason for this is the new Liberal-National coalition majority in the Senate. The actual evidence is difficult to discover but apparently includes a slight reduction in the number of questions allocated to the opposition in the Senate and the provision of a regular question to the new Family First senator. In other words, it is a change in the composition of questions in the Senate to reflect the changing composition of the Senate itself—hardly revolutionary you would have thought. The implication in the claims has been that the democratic decision of the Australian people in the last half-Senate election throughout Australia but particularly in Queensland has somehow produced a reduction in democratic accountability. A new spam email campaign has even begun to deluge thousands of the computers of unsuspecting Australians, warning of alleged threats that flow from the public’s democratic decision to give the coalition a majority in the Senate.

speech.para: The arrogance and falsity of this squealing is hard to reconcile with reality. It is especially ridiculous to make such claims about Australia’s parliamentary system, which is without doubt the most democratically accountable in the world. Unlike President George Bush, who does not sit in a parliament and therefore does not answer questions, and British Prime Minister Tony Blair, who attends the House of Commons to answer questions roughly about once a week, our Prime Minister attends question time every single sitting day and, on top of that, takes more questions each day than any previous occupant of the prime ministership in living memory. Compare this to the situation under former Prime Minister Paul Keating whereby the most critical part of the parliamentary day in terms of the accountability of the executive—question time—was gutted by his cynical decision to introduce a roster system. Question time literally became a part-time job for ministers and the Prime Minister, with them attending only every second day. To make matters worse, the number of questions answered throughout question time was slowly reduced to 10 or fewer over a period of no more than 45 minutes. Today the asking of 20 questions every day and the attendance of every minister and the Prime Minister every day have rightly become accepted as normal, such that the past poor performance has been forgotten. But it wasn’t always ‘normal’ and that improvement should be recognised.

Labor—and other critics of parliament in general—might not like to admit it but, in terms of parliamentary accountability as measured by question time statistics, the Howard government generally, and the Prime Minister in particular, are answering more questions than any previous government. Whereas Bob Hawke answered 1,551 questions without notice over his eight years and nine months as Prime Minister, Prime Minister Howard has answered 2,401 over the same period—850, or 54 per cent, more over the same period. Prior to the start of this sitting week, he had answered a further 185 this year. If you look at Bob Hawke’s period, you see that the Prime Minister exceeded Bob Hawke’s total in just over five years. Whilst the figure for the Fraser government was better than the figure for the period of the Hawke government, Prime Minister John Howard exceeded Malcolm Fraser’s entire seven-year total in about five years. Former Prime Minister Keating was undoubtedly the least accountable, answering just 719 questions in his four years and three months as Prime Minister—a total that Prime Minister Howard eclipsed in just two years and one month.

Just as importantly, democratic accountability is a key feature of our parliamentary institutions. It is also a key feature of our political culture, extending way beyond the parliament itself. Daily press conferences, televisions interviews and radio interviews mean a constant level of accountability that is just not seen elsewhere. Tony Blair’s and George Bush’s weekly media appearances may be frequent but they do not number close to those of the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister, the Treasurer or senior ministers. Talkback radio, a home-grown feature of Australian politics whereby citizens can ring up and ask the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and the Leader of the National Party of Australia, or the Treasurer any question on any topic, is something that you do not see overseas. That is a level of accountability that is peculiar to Australia and it makes our nation truly one of the most democratic and accountable nations in the world. It would be better for the critics to fess up now to what they are truly upset about—the decision that their fellow Australians took last October. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 17 November 2004:

quote.para: What (a) number and (b) percentage of all taxpayers failed to lodge an income tax return during each of the financial years ended 30 June 1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001 and 2002.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Brough

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

quote.para: Because the requirement to lodge an income tax return is dependant on an individual’s own circumstances, the Tax Office is not able to determine an authoritative lodgment gap in any year.
Enforcement activity to support improved levels of compliance with lodgment obligations is conducted by the Tax Office on an ongoing basis.
The table below sets out actual income tax return lodgments received to 31 October of the years following each of the years to which income relates.
The second table sets out as at 17 June 2005 the increase in income tax return lodgments after 31 October of the year following each of the financial years to which income relates.
This gives an indication of additional lodgments secured following Tax Office compliance activity.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, in writing, on 17 November 2004:

item.para: Is he aware that the Police Association of New South Wales is seeking a fairer and more equitable method of calculating the superannuation surcharge for NSW police who are members of the Police Superannuation Scheme.

Is he aware that police officers who are members of the Police Superannuation Scheme are excluded from the Workers’ Compensation Act 1987 and that they are experiencing abnormally high levels of retirement on medical grounds.
Is he aware that members who remain in the Police Superannuation Scheme are required to pay an ever-increasing surcharge contribution.

Will he review the Government’s policy to allow the Commissioner of Taxation to make changes to the calculation of the surcharge for affected police to ensure fairness and equity with other occupations; if not, why not.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Brough

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: to (4) Yes, I am aware of the campaign by the Police Association of New South Wales for approval of an alternative method for determining their members’ surchargeable employer contributions. I have met with the Police Association of New South Wales and discussed the matter in more detail.

Whilst the issue is due largely to the structure of the fund – a matter for NSW – the Treasurer has announced the abolition of the superannuation surcharge. I note the Australian Labor Party oppose the abolition of the superannuation surcharge.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 29 November 2004:

item.para: Is he aware that Kirribilli House was never intended to be the primary residence of the Prime Minister.
Does he recall that the reason he gave for using Kirribilli House as his primary residence was that he had dependent children attending schools in Sydney when he became Prime Minister.
Can he indicate how many of his children (a) continue to reside at Kirribilli House, (b) continue to attend school, and (c) continue to be dependent.
Can he say when he will move his official primary residence to the Lodge in Canberra.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: There was never any restriction to the intended use of Kirribilli House. Since 1957, all Prime Ministers have used Kirribilli House as a residence.

to (4) My existing arrangements are within entitlement. When residing at Kirribilli House, my non-dependent children pay a contribution for accommodation and sustenance, as determined by my department. Any proper comparison of costs between comparable periods of my term of office and Mr Keating’s term of office indicate my arrangements have not incurred additional costs to the Commonwealth. I do not intend altering my current arrangements.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 8 February 2005:

item.para: How many times has he visited the electoral division of (a) Cunningham, (b) Throsby, (c) Gilmore, (d) Hughes, and (e) Hume from 1996 to 2004.
What were the dates and purposes of each of his visits to these electoral divisions.

Can he say how many times the (a) Hon. R. J. L. Hawke, and (b) Hon. P. J. Keating visit the electoral division of (a) Cunningham, (b) Throsby, (c) Gilmore, (d) Hughes, and (e) Hume during his term of office.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: to (3) The Prime Minister regularly visits many different regions, cities, towns and suburbs throughout the nation and has done so since his election in 1996.
Those visits receive local press coverage.
The honourable member is referred to easily available public sources such as local community and Sydney wide media.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

quote.para: For each of the last five years, what are the details and sum of each grant and service payment by the Minister’s department and agencies within the Minister’s portfolio to (a) the Hillsong Foundation, and (b) its associated entities.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: In the last five years, of the Minister’s department and agencies, only the Health Insurance Commission has made a grant to the Hillsong Foundation and its associated entities.

The payment made by HIC was for $825 and was part of a larger payment to 138 other vendors for HIC Online grants. This followed the Hillsong Health Centre agreeing to take up HIC Online and being eligible for the grant.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 7 March 2005:

item.para: Is the Minister aware of Mr Lajos (Ludwig) Polgar who is currently living in Fern Tree Gully in Melbourne.

Is the Minister aware of the recent report in Magyar Elet, an Hungarian language newspaper in Melbourne, that Mr Polgar said that at 18 years of age he joined the Hungarian national-socialist movement and remained a member until he was 24 years of age.
Is the Minister able to produce Mr Polgar’s 1949 application to migrate to Australia from Hungary.
Is the Minister able to provide records on the activities Mr Polgar has been involved in since arriving in Australia and on what he said was his occupation and history prior to arriving in Australia.
Is the Minister aware of the organisation called Arrow Cross Party which was the national-socialist movement of which Mr Polgar was a member in Hungary.

Is the Minister aware that members of this organisation roamed the streets of Hungary during 1944 in quasi-military uniforms, hunting-down Jews and sending them to Auschwitz or shooting them and throwing them into the Danube River.
Can the Minister say whether any other members of the Arrow Cross Party were allowed to enter Australia after World War II.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr John Cobb

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: I am now aware of Mr Lajos Polgar.
I have now been made aware of the report.
All files of that age are sent to National Archives. I am advised that a search has been conducted by National Archives in Melbourne and Mr Polgar’s migration file from 1949 cannot be located.

I am not able to provide records on the activities Mr Polgar has been involved in since arriving in Australia. However, I can advise that Mr Polgar stated on his application for Australian citizenship: that his previous occupations before entering Australia were a soldier, diplomat and department manager, and that he lived in Hungary up until 1944, when he then travelled to Germany before migrating to Australia.
I am now aware of the organisation.
I am now aware of some of the activities of members of the Arrow Cross Party in Hungary during World War II.
The Department has advised that it does not have any information on the entry of members of the Arrow Cross Party.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs: Legal Action

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 March 2005:

item.para: What commitment has the Minister’s department given to support staff named in legal action by dissatisfied clients.
How many DIMIA staff have been named personally in legal action by dissatisfied clients.
What guarantees of indemnity exist for financial damages or penalties awarded against staff, even when the staff member has shown due diligence in an affected case.
Why have some staff not been informed that they have been named in an action in relation to their duties as a DIMIA officer.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr John Cobb

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: The Attorney-General issued Legal Services Directions with effect from 1 September 1999 that set the Government’s policy for providing assistance in relation to legal proceedings (including potential legal proceedings) as well as inquests, inquiries and subpoenas to a Commonwealth employee (including former employees). In the context of this policy, Agency Heads may determine the extent of indemnification for legal representation and any costs or damages that may become payable.

In the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) it is standard practice that all cases, where an employee is named in legal proceedings, be referred immediately to the Assistant Secretary, Legal Services and Litigation Branch, who ensures that a request for financial assistance is made to the Secretary, on behalf of the employee, in accordance with the Legal Services Directions.
Where the Secretary agrees to the provision of financial assistance to an employee:
the named employee is regularly updated on the progress of the case; and
assistance and guidance is provided to the employee for preparation of any material or statements relevant to the case, as appropriate.

Managers and supervisors of employees named in legal proceedings are required to be sympathetic to these staff and provide the appropriate facilities, support and guidance including allowing reasonable time off for the employee to prepare material/statements, give evidence and attend to matters related to the legal proceedings as well as attend to their personal and emotional needs as appropriate
If an employee is feeling anxious about being named in legal proceedings they are encouraged to arrange and attend counselling with the Department’s Employee Assistance Program provider.
The Department does not collect statistical data on the number of staff named personally in legal proceedings by dissatisfied clients.

While no formal guarantee of indemnity to cover financial damages or penalties can be given, the Department would provide financial assistance, in accordance with the Legal Services Directions, to an employee named in legal proceedings in all cases where the employee acted reasonably and responsibly in the performance of their duties.

The Government’s policy does not preclude the provision of assistance to an employee named in legal proceedings who has acted, or is alleged to have acted, negligently (i.e. they failed to exercise the legal standard of ‘reasonable care’ owed in the circumstances). Rather, a decision not to provide assistance to an employee would only be appropriate in those cases where an employee’s conduct in a matter involved serious or wilful misconduct or culpable negligence.

It is departmental policy to inform DIMIA officers, to the extent possible, if they are named as respondents in legal proceedings. The Department advises that it is not aware of a situation where an officer has not been informed that they were named as a respondent in legal proceedings.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

quote.para: What target has the Government set for gross expenditure on research and development as a proportion of GDP and how will this target be met?

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources
talker.name: Mr Ian Macfarlane

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Australia’s gross expenditure on R&D (GERD) has been steadily increasing, and in 2002-03 reached $12 250 million (in current prices), an increase of 17.6% on 2000-01. GERD as a proportion of GDP was 1.62% in 2002-03, representing an increase of 0.07 percentage points since 2000-01 when it was 1.55%. This increase of 0.07 percentage points is higher than the OECD average growth of 0.02 and the EU-15 average growth of 0.05 over the two year period. Australia’s GERD as a percentage of GDP has been rising since 1998-99, when it was 1.51%.

Sound innovation policy and performance is much broader than simply developing expenditure targets. Businesses expenditure on R&D, for example, is impacted by a range of issues. It is the creation of an environment conducive to business investment in R&D and its commercialisation as well as the availability of mechanisms to address market failures – and not targets – which will facilitate growth and employment. For example, Australia’s industry structure is quite different from that of many other developed nations, with a long standing strength in resource industries such as agriculture and mining. More recently, industry has invested heavily in ICT and there is a growing biotechnology industry in Australia. Unlike many of our competitors, however, we do not have large Australian aerospace and pharmaceutical industries.

The Government’s policy statements, such as Backing Australia’s Ability (2001) and Backing Australia’s Ability, Building Our Future Through Science and Innovation (2004), implements this approach and focuses on delivering outcomes. And the data shows our policies are working.

quote.para: Please Note:

Total Australian Government funding for government schools is not reported at the level of detail requested. Australian Government General Recurrent Grants for government schools are provided to the government education authority in each State or Territory, on the basis of total enrolments. The State or Territory determines where the grants are used. Payments to individual schools are not recorded. Where payments to individual schools are recorded for particular Australian Government programmes or initiatives this information is provided.
Capital Grants funding for State schools in New South Wales for 2004 is not yet available

* These non-government schools are all members of the New South Wales Catholic Education Commission. The actual allocation to each member school is made by the system authority. Figures provided here reflect funding provided to the system in respect of enrolments at individual schools.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: In respect of the visit by the Governor-General to Great Britain to attend the wedding of Prince Charles, (a) what are the guidelines concerning the approval of overseas travel by the Governor-General, (b) who accompanied the Governor-General, (c) what was the travel itinerary of the Governor-General and his party, and (d) what was the itemised cost of the travel, accommodation and meals of the Governor-General and his party.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The established procedure is for the Governor-General to write seeking my concurrence to any proposals for overseas travel. The Governor-General may also travel at the request of the government. In this case, the Governor-General was invited to attend the wedding of Prince Charles and Mrs Camilla Parker Bowles by Her Majesty The Queen and HRH The Duke of Edinburgh.
The Official Secretary to the Governor-General has provided the following information:

item.label: (b)
item.para: Her Excellency Mrs Jeffery, personal staff (2), Federal Agents (2).

item.label: (c)
item.para: Friday 8 April 2005
Depart Italy / Arrive London.
Saturday 9 April 2005
Attend Service of Prayer and Dedication following the marriage of HRH The Prince of Wales and Mrs Camilla Parker Bowles.
Attend reception hosted by Her Majesty The Queen and HRH The Duke of Edinburgh in celebration of the marriage of HRH The Prince of Wales and Mrs Camilla Parker Bowles.
Sunday 10 April 2005
Depart London for Australia.

item.label: (d)
item.para: It is not possible to identify separately the cost of travel to the UK. The total cost of travel to Italy and the UK is identified in the response to part 1(a) of Question No. 1198. Accommodation and meal costs totalled $10,256. (Note: air travel Canberra-Sydney-Canberra was undertaken using VIP aircraft paid by the Department of Defence; the costs include only expenses of Their Excellencies and their staff.)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: Can he confirm that recipients of the age pension receive a utilities allowance twice a year; if so, what is the amount of the utilities allowance paid to (a) single and (b) couple pensioners.
Can he explain why people in receipt of disability support pensions and other income support under age pension age do not receive a utilities allowance.
Can he explain why couples of age pension age are paid, on an individual basis, half the amount of utilities allowance that a single eligible person would receive.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Recipients of income support payments who are of age pension age automatically receive utilities allowance instalments each March and September. The annual rate of utilities allowance;

item.label: (a)
item.para: for a single person, is currently $100, with the first $50 instalment paid in March 2005, and

item.label: (b)
item.para: for each member of a couple, is currently $50, with the first $25 instalment paid in March 2005.
The second instalment of utilities allowance is due in September 2005 and will be adjusted to Consumer Price Index rises.

The utilities allowance forms part of the Australian Government’s 2004 election commitment to provide additional assistance to senior Australians, being those of Age (or Veteran) pension age. These measures were in recognition of the valuable contributions that Australian seniors have made, and continue to make within the community. The utilities allowance is not payable to income support recipients who are of working age.

The Australian Government pays disability support pensioners a higher rate of income support than it pays to other workforce age customers, and DSP has a more generous income taper rate. Disability support pensioners also receive pharmaceutical allowance, telephone allowance if they are telephone subscribers, and have access to the pensioner education supplement, and a range of concessions through the pensioner concession card. Disability support pension is also not taxable, whereas other pensions (including age pension) and allowances are taxable.

The payment rates of utilities allowance follow the same rules as a number of other supplementary payments where the couple (combined) rate is the same as the single person rate. Each eligible ‘pensioner household’ receives the same amount of utilities allowance, reflecting the reality that couples in the same household can take advantage of sharing the benefits of utilities within the household.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: Further to the answers to question Nos 138 and 139 (Hansard, 16 February 2005, page 163), why did the Governor of Victoria, His Excellency John Landy AC MBE serve as Administrator of the Commonwealth during the absence of the Governor-General overseas from 6 to 12 April 2005, instead of the most senior State Governor, the Governor of Western Australia His Excellency Lieutenant-General John Sanderson, AC.
Why was the Governor of Western Australia unavailable to serve as Administrator of the Commonwealth on this occasion.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The most senior State Governor, His Excellency Lieutenant General John Sanderson AC, was not available to assume the administration of the Commonwealth during the Governor-General’s absence overseas in April 2005. The next most senior State Governor, Mr John Landy AC MBE, was available to undertake that role.

His Excellency Lieutenant General John Sanderson AC indicated he was unable to perform the duties of Administrator of the Commonwealth on that occasion owing to longstanding commitments in Western Australia.

Which aspects of the National Protocols do these campuses or controlled entities fail to comply with.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: At the Sustaining Prosperity Conference on 31 March 2005 I did not state that any universities operate campuses or controlled entities which do not comply with the National Protocols for Higher Education Approval Processes.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: Is he aware of the Report of the Inquiry into Australian Intelligence Agencies dated July 2004.
What steps has the Government taken to implement each of the recommendations in the report.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question to the Attorney-General is as follows:

item.para: Yes.

Progress has been rapid in implementing the more than twenty major recommendations made in the report of the Inquiry into Australian Intelligence Agencies. Action has commenced on all of the recommendations, including several that take the form of ongoing guidance to the intelligence agencies, eg. that ONA produce a greater number of National Assessments. Recommendations implemented to date include:
a. provision of funding for the expansion of ONA’s analytic capacity which has enabled ONA to increase the number of its analysts and to restructure in accordance with the Inquiry’s proposals;
b. establishment of the ONA-chaired Foreign Intelligence Coordination Committee which has met monthly since August 2004;

c. development of provisions to implement all of the legislative changes recommended in the Inquiry Report, which were introduced into Parliament on 16 June 2005 as major elements of the Intelligence Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. These include provisions to establish a legislative basis for DIGO’s functions and accountabilities; to give clearer and stronger authority for ONA’s co-ordination and evaluation roles; to amend provisions relating to ONA’s National Assessments Board; and to give effect to recommendations to expand the mandates of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD and of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security.
d. provision of funding for the expansion of accommodation facilities for ONA and ASIO;
e. finalisation of a new mandate for DIO focusing its work more closely on supporting the ADF;
f. increased consultation between DIO and ONA on their forward work programmes, including attendance at each other’s weekly requirements meetings.
g. provision of funding and other measures to enhance key language capabilities;
h. development of a strategy to redress the shortfall of military personnel assigned to the Defence intelligence agencies;
i. the appointment of a senior (two-star) military officer as Director of DIO when that position became vacant;
j. creation of one new Deputy Director position each in DIO and DSD;
k. development of a DIGO customer engagement strategy;
l. transfer of DFAT’s Open Source Unit and its budget to ONA;
m. establishment of community-wide training initiatives through the commencement of an AIC-wide induction course;
n. increase in the production of ONA National Assessments;
o. development of a strategy for IT connectivity and collaborative intelligence production within the intelligence community;
p. integration of the previously separate national and defence intelligence priorities systems; and

q. agreement on steps developed by PM&C to align annual performance reporting, priority-setting and resource allocation mechanisms for the foreign intelligence community, which was utilised in part for the first time in the presentation of advice to Ministers in late 2004.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 12 May 2005:

item.para: How many Job Network providers are currently operating in the Fairfield/Liverpool Employment Service Area (ESA) and what are their names and addresses.
How many job seekers are currently registered with each Job Network employment services provider in the Fairfield/Liverpool ESA.

For the years 2002, 2003 and 2004, how many (a) Newstart and (b) Youth Allowance recipients were placed in jobs through assistance from Job Network providers in (i) Australia and (ii) the Fairfield/Liverpool ESA.

For the years 2002, 2003 and 2004, how many long-term unemployed people (a) in total, and (b) as a proportion of all unemployed people, participated in (i) intensive assistance programs and (ii) the Active Participation Model in the Fairfield/Liverpool ESA.

According to the Post Program Monitoring survey, (a) how many job seekers who participated in intensive assistance in the Fairfield/Liverpool ESA found employment and (b) what proportion who participated in intensive assistance in the Fairfield/Liverpool ESA found (i) full-time, (ii) part-time and (iii) casual employment in 2002, 2003 and 2004.
How many Community Work Co-ordinators are currently operating in the Fairfield/Liverpool ESA and what are their names and addresses.
Will he provide a description of each individual activity run by each Community Work Co-ordinator in the Fairfield/Liverpool ESA in 2004.

According to the Post Program Monitoring survey, (a) how many job seekers who participated in a Work for the Dole activity in the Fairfield/Liverpool ESA found employment and (b) what proportion who participated in a Work for the Dole activity in the Fairfield/Liverpool ESA found (i) full-time, (ii) part-time and (iii) casual employment in 2002, 2003, and 2004.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr Andrews

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: and (2) There are currently 25 Job Network members and other Job Placement Organisations (JPO) operating in the Fairfield/Liverpool ESA. Their names, office locations and the number of job seekers on their caseloads are shown in Table 1.

Job Network is administered on the basis of 19 Labour Market Regions and 137 Employment Services Areas (ESAs). Job seekers choose Job Network Members(JNM) for a variety of reasons including location, proximity to transport routes and Centrelink offices, or the satisfaction of friends and others. Job seekers residing in one ESA may elect to be assisted through Job Network sites located in adjoining ESAs.

quote.para: Table 1 Job Network Sites - Fairfield/Liverpool ESA

entry.para: Board of Adult Multicultural Education Services

Cnr Horsley Dr and Elizabeth St
Jobs and Careers Services Pty Limited
Level 1, Shop 28, Viet Hoa Shopping Centre

quote.para: *JNM = Job Network member.
*JPO = Job Placement Organisation.

Notes: Site details and job seeker numbers are as at 6 May 2005. Caseload numbers are for the “JN Active Caseload”, that is job seekers currently in assistance with a JN site or very recently referred for assistance. Caseload numbers are at a point in time and change as job seekers are referred to a site or exit assistance at the site. JPOs are not allocated a specific business share, but compete to secure vacancies from employers and to refer eligible job seekers.

item.para: The numbers of (a) Newstart and (b) Youth Allowance (Other) recipients placed into jobs by Job Network providers and other Job Placement Organisations in the years 2002, 2003 and 2004, in (i) Australia and (ii) the Fairfield/Liverpool ESA are shown in Table 2.

item.para: No question.

The Post-Programme Monitoring (PPM) survey conducted by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations (DEWR) measures job seekers’ outcomes three months after they have left assistance. PPM survey results are an estimate of outcomes levels based on responses from a sample of clients rather than the full population.

item.para: Work for the Dole is a work experience programme. Employment is not a stated objective of the programme, however, the valuable work experience gained through the programme combined with the continued support of the Job Network, supports the objectives of the APM.

The Post-Programme Monitoring (PPM) survey conducted by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations (DEWR) measures job seekers’ outcomes three months after they have left assistance. PPM survey results are an estimate of outcomes levels based on responses from a sample of clients rather than the full population.

Aggregated outcomes estimates for Work for the Dole for the Fairfield/Liverpool ESA are shown in Table 8. Table 8 includes (a) the total proportion in employment and (b) the proportions in (i) full-time, (ii) part-time and (iii) casual employment 3 months after exiting their placements.

quote.para: Table 8 Work for the Dole Post Programme Monitoring Outcomes
Fairfield/Liverpool ESA

1 Casual employment includes employment on a temporary, seasonal or casual basis as reported by respondents to the PPM survey. Clients responding to the survey as being in casual employment are also counted in the total employment, full-time employment and part-time employment figures

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 20 May 2005:

item.para: Is his department conducting a survey on work and family commitments; if so, how has the survey sample been selected and what cohort is it intended to represent.
Have consultants or contractors been engaged to conduct or advise on the conduct of the survey; if so, who was so engaged and, in each case, for what services and at what cost.

Does the survey ask (a) what is your average weekly income before tax, (b) how long have you been with this company, (c) have you received a pay rise in the last year, (d) do you have access to a performance bonus, (e) are you a member of a union, (f) are you paid under an Award, a Certified Agreement (CA), or an Australian Workplace Agreement (AWA), (g) Please circle a number to indicate your level of agreement or disagreement with these statements: I get paid fairly for the things I do in my job; I do lots of different tasks in my job; I feel secure about my future in my job; My job is very stressful; This is a good place to work; I often think about leaving my job, (h) Do you: Own your own house with no mortgage; Own your own house with a mortgage; Rent private; Rent public/community/housing commission; Other (please specify); if so, can he explain how the questions relate to the balance of work and family commitments.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr Andrews

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: My department is conducting a pilot survey on work and family commitments. The sample consists of two groups:
A sample drawn from the white pages telephone directory to represent the general population; and
A sample of those on sole parent pensions to represent sole parents.
The department will conduct a further pilot test in August before conducting the main survey. The size and source of the sample for the further pilot and main survey have not yet been determined.

The South Australian Centre for Economic Studies was contracted in April 2004 to assist with the design and preparation of the first pilot survey at a cost of $27,920. The University of Queensland Social Research Centre was contracted in June 2005 to provide further assistance in the design and preparation of the second pilot survey at a cost of $25,031.

Salmat has been contracted to provide mailhouse services and Green and Green has been contracted to provide data entry and telephone interviewing services. The total cost of these consultancies is expected to be around $50,000.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: , (b), (c), (d), (e), (f), (h). Yes. The questions relate to conditions in the workplace and employee’s perceptions about their work and financial security.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 23 May 2005:

item.para: Has the Minister read the article titled ‘A department of mean spirit’ in The Sydney Morning Herald on 7 May 2005 which reported that in the past fortnight 50 East Timorese asylum seekers have received letters from the Department of Immigration, Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs informing them that the Minister has decided not to use her discretion to grant them a visa and that they should now make arrangements to leave Australia.
How many of these applicants came to Australia as survivors of the Santa Cruz Massacre in Dili in 1991.

Can the Minister confirm that most of the applicants (a) have been living in Australia for at least ten years, (b) have learnt English, (c) have held stable jobs, and (d) have young families attending Australian primary and high schools; if not, why not.

Can the Minister confirm that other East Timorese asylum seekers, including some family members of the 50 applicants, have been granted permanent residency in Australia; if not, why not, if so, what are the details.
Will the Minister reconsider and grant the 50 East Timorese asylum seekers permanent residency in Australia; if so, when; if not, why not.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr John Cobb

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Yes.
Information provided to my Department indicates that at least 12 of the East Timorese claimed to have been present at the Dili Santa Cruz Massacre in 1991.
A manual examination of information available on the East Timorese who had been notified that their request for ministerial intervention was unsuccessful indicates that:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Twenty have lived in Australia for at least ten years;

item.label: (b)
item.para: Most of the individuals appear to have learnt English to some extent;

item.label: (c)
item.para: At least 25 of the individuals have jobs; and

item.label: (d)
item.para: There are five families with pre-school and school-aged children.

and (5) Some 1440 East Timorese asylum seekers had been granted permanent residence as at the end of June 2005. I have decided to reconsider the residual group of East Timorese cases on their individual merits. Forty-seven additional people have been asked to undertake further visa checks so that I can progress my consideration of the possible grant of permanent visas to them, leaving six of the group in respect of whom I have declined to intervene. These six people have relatives granted permanent residence in Australia. The six people have again been offered the Government’s reintegration package to assist them to return to East Timor.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 24 May 2005:

item.para: To what extent has the Government investigated the phenomena of Phoenix companies.
What measures, if any, have been adopted to prevent the use of Phoenix companies to avoid legitimate debts.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Brough

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: The Commissioner of Taxation advised me that since 1998 the Tax Office has maintained a planned and co-ordinated focus on individuals who use, or promote the use of, successive company structures to intentionally evade payment of taxes.

A major focus of the Tax Office has been on serial (Phoenix) offenders who use deliberate and fraudulent methods to avoid their obligations. During the past six years over $325 million in tax and penalties has been raised by the Tax Office in targeting these individuals and their entities.

The Tax Office has established a number of consultative forums with the building and construction industry where Phoenix companies have been widely reported, which provide assistance in developing strategies to address these practices.

The Tax Office provided written submissions to the ‘Royal Commission into the Building and Construction Industry’ and to the ‘Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services’, both of which considered Phoenix companies.
The Tax Office adopts a range of strategies to manage phoenix arrangements, including:
vigilant pursuit of unlodged company returns and outstanding liabilities, so as to minimise the potential benefits which could accrue from phoenix activity;
the provision of indemnities to liquidators so that they may pursue assets that have been transferred out of the company by way of voidable transactions;

the routine application of the director penalty provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to make directors personally liable for the unpaid PAYG Withholding component of their company’s tax debts;
the ongoing monitoring of company directors identified as participating in Phoenix arrangements;
the utilisation of the Proceeds of Crimes Act to recover assets illegally acquired by Phoenix operators;
the referral of cases suitable for prosecution to the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions; and
working with State and Federal Agencies to exchange information in relation to Phoenix companies.

The Tax Office is also modifying its work practices to make greater use of the provisions within the Corporations Act 2001 by which directors can be compelled to pay compensation for debts that they allowed the company to accrue at a time when it was obviously insolvent.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 24 May 2005:

item.para: Is the Minister aware that the 50 East Timorese who are being sent back to Timor have lived in Australia for 10 years and that some have children who were born here.
Would the Minister provide details of the serious character grounds that were given as the reason why the 50 East Timorese are being sent back to East Timor.
Will the Minister reconsider the decision to send the 50 East Timorese back to Timor and allow them to stay in Australia.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr John Cobb

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Fifty East Timorese are not being sent back to Timor. I have asked 47 of the residual group of East Timorese to undertake relevant visa checks, so that I can progress my consideration of the possible grant of permanent visas to them. I have confirmed the decision to decline to intervene in relation only to six of the East Timorese. They have again been offered the Government’s reintegration package to assist them to return to East Timor. I am aware that three of those six people have lived in Australia for at least 10 years. The other three have been in Australia for eight and a half years. None of these six applicants have children born in Australia.

In considering whether to exercise Ministerial discretion in these cases, a range of factors were taken into account. I am under no obligation to provide any explanation for not using the intervention power in particular cases.

I have decided to reconsider the residual group of East Timorese cases on their individual merits. As set out in answer to (1), 47 people have been asked to undertake further checks so that I can progress my consideration of the possible grant of permanent visas to them. I have confirmed the decision to decline to intervene in relation to six people in the group. These people have again been offered the Government’s reintegration package to assist them to return to East Timor.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 26 May 2005:

item.para: Further to the answer to question No. 649 (Hansard, 24 May 2005, page 69), why does the Government consider that the current arrangements for the three existing commercial television licences appear to be working well in providing quality free-to-air television to the Australian public.

Why has the review of the moratorium on the allocation of new commercial television broadcasting licences not specifically addressed the issue of whether there should be a fourth free-to-air television licence issued to another media company.

Is he aware that the media proprietor, Mr John Singleton, has publicly stated that his company is interested in operating a fourth television network in Australia that would broadcast 100% Australian content.
Did Mr Singleton make a formal submission to the Government concerning its review of commercial television licences.
How many submissions to the Government’s review of commercial television licences were received.
How many submissions indicated support for a fourth free-to-air television licence.
How many submissions opposed a fourth free-to-air television licence.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Commercial broadcasting services are available throughout Australia free to air and have been provided in a stable viewing environment for some time. These services operate in a legislative environment which aims to meet a range of public policy objectives including to provide a diverse range of services, to play a role in developing and reflecting a sense of Australian identity, to protect children from exposure to harmful program material, and to provide high quality and innovative programming. The Government considers that overall these arrangements are working well but, nevertheless, as always will look to refine these arrangements where appropriate. Part of this process is the series of statutory reviews which have been and are being conducted.

The purpose of the review of the provision of commercial television broadcasting services after 31 December 2006 is not to consider the matter of whether a licence for a fourth commercial television network should be issued.
I am aware of reports to that effect.
No.
Eighteen.

and (7) A range of views were expressed in submissions to the review of the provision of commercial television broadcasting services after 31 December 2006. The submissions have been made publicly available and can be accessed from the website of the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts http://www.dcita.gov.au/broad/policy_reviews/digital _broadcasting_policy_reviews/review_of_the_provision_of_commercial_television_broadcasting_services_after_31_december_2006.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 1 June 2005:

item.para: How many Australian Workplace Agreements (AWAs) have been filed with the Employment Advocate.
What proportion of federal agreements are AWAs.
What is the average number of (a) clauses and (b) pages in AWAs.
What proportion of AWAs are rejected by the Employment Advocate on the grounds that they breach the Workplace Relations Act 1996.
How many people are employed by the Employment Advocate.
What increases in staffing levels of the Employment Advocate will be required as a result of the recently announced changes to Australia’s industrial relations system.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr Andrews

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Between the inception of the Office of the Employment Advocate in 1997 and 31 May 2005, a total of 739,437 Australian workplace agreements (AWAs) have been filed.

An estimated 447,300 AWAs and 15,800 certified agreements are currently in operation (as at 31 May 2005). As each AWA is an individual agreement, it is counted as one federal agreement in its own right. Similarly, each collective agreement is counted as one federal agreement, regardless of the number of employees covered. Therefore, on this basis, 97 per cent of federal agreements are AWAs.

However, in terms of employees covered by AWAs, the proportion is considerably lower because only one employee is covered by each AWA. In the case of CAs, each agreement may cover hundreds or even thousands of employees. Therefore, it is estimated that 22 per cent of employees on federal agreements are covered by an AWA.
The OEA does not record the number of clauses contained in AWAs, nor does it record the page length of AWAs.

In the current financial year to date (as at 31 May 2005), 0.5 per cent of AWAs finalised have been refused for not meeting the requirements of s170VPA(1) of the Workplace Relations Act 1996, and an additional 0.7 per cent have been referred to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission under s170VPB(3) of the Act.
As at 31 May 2005, a total of 188 people were employed in the Office of the Employment Advocate.
The Department of Employment and Workplace Relations is not now in a position to estimate the impact on OEA staffing levels of the Government’s proposed workplace relations reforms.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 1 June 2005:

item.para: What qualifications will be required of the people to be appointed to the Fair Pay Commission.
What will be the duration of appointments to the Fair Pay Commission.
Who will be responsible for appointing Fair Pay Commissioners.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
