talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: No decision has yet been made on this matter. However, the Government has indicated that, when appointing the Commission, it will look at appointing one commissioner from an employee background, one from an employer or business background and at least one labour market economist.
No decision has yet been made on this matter.
No decision has yet been made on this matter.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 1 June 2005:

item.para: Has the Minister seen the article ‘Detention policy fails the test of humanity’ in The Australian on 26 May 2005 in which the Liberal member for Pearce wrote “to me no less important, for reasons of conscience, to engage in a debate on asylum-seeker policy, a policy that fails the foundation test of upholding human life and human dignity”.

Has the Minister seen the article ‘Labor MPs back detention bills’ in the Financial Review on 30 May 2005 which reported that “there is broad Labor support for Liberal Petro Georgiou’s private bills to reform detention laws”.

Is the Minister aware that on 26 June 2003 the former Shadow Minister for Immigration, the Member for Lalor, moved a second reading amendment to the Migration Amendment (Duration of Detention) Bill 2003 asking the House to (a) immediately ensure that children and their families are taken out of high security detention centres and housed in alternative detention arrangements, (b) immediately ensure that all unaccompanied children are placed into foster or community care arrangements, (c) honour the Prime Minister’s statements that contact with fathers is vital for children by allowing complete family units to be together in alternative detention arrangements, and (d) acknowledge the numerous reports from mental health professionals that life behind razor wire is fundamentally damaging to children, and that this amendment was defeated; if not, why not.

Will the Minister amend migration legislation to implement Labor Party policy to (a) remove children from detention, (b) process ninety-per cent of people in detention within ninety days, (c) ensure independent review of all cases of detention beyond ninety days and (d) ensure certainty for people on Temporary Protection Visas; if so, when, if not, why not.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr John Cobb

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
I refer to the changes announced by the Prime Minister on 17 June 2005 and to the Migration Amendment (Detention Arrangements) Act 2005.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 1 June 2005:

item.para: Further to the answer to question No. 650 (Hansard, 25 May 2005, page 113), did the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) find that Sydney Christian Broadcasters (SCB) had identified a significant demand for an additional community service.
Did the ABA determine that SCB has the capacity to provide a community broadcasting service on 1386 AM; if not, what reasons did the ABA have for finding otherwise.

When the ABA called for further public comment on the future of the service on 1386 AM, how many (a) letters from the public and (b) other submissions did it receive (i) in favour and (ii) opposed to the proposed service to be operated by SCB.
Were the submissions on the future of the service on 1386 AM open for public comment.

Did the ABA review the submission made by SCB contesting the ABA’s findings in deciding not to grant SCB the licence, in particular, SCB’s claim that it would reasonably expect a potential audience of between 237,000 and 755,000 people; if so, will the Minister provide a copy of the ABA’s findings; if no review was undertaken, will the Minister explain why not.

Did the ABA consider the surveys and research undertaken by Rhema Sydney in its submissions; if so, did the ABA accept the veracity of the information submitted; if the ABA did not consider the information and research submitted, will the Minister explain why not.
Did the ABA find the research data submitted by SCB to prove its case for the demand for an additional Christian community broadcasting service to be reliable.
Is the 1386 AM frequency (a) still designated and (b) available for community use.

Did the ABA General Manager in a public address to the Association of Christian Broadcasters in Manly in June 2004 (a) admit that the ABA had received several submissions in favour of the Rhema Sydney proposal in response to the ABA’s invitation and call for further public comment as to the future use of the 1386 AM frequency in Sydney and that it had also received some 284 letters of support, and (b) indicate that the ABA would be delivering its findings and responses by the end of July 2004.
Has the ABA received a commercial-in-confidence submission on the 1386 AM frequency from Commercial Radio Australia (CRA); if so, will the ABA make a decision based on this submission.

Can the Minister confirm that the decision of the future use of the 1386 AM frequency is a merit-based process and that the call for further public submissions is part of an open and transparent process; if so, can the Minister explain how the public interest is being served when this does not appear to be the case.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: In Sydney Christian Broadcaster’s (SCB) submission to the ABA’s discussion paper on options for the future use of 1386 kHz, it states that there is significant demand for an additional community broadcasting service in Sydney. The Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) will take SCB’s submission into consideration at the time that it makes a decision in relation to the future use of 1386 kHz in Sydney. Furthermore, the ABA released a discussion paper on 19 May 2005 seeking submissions on whether to put in place restrictions on planning or allocating new radio services on the AM band so as to not further reduce the already limited capacity to introduce digital radio services. SCB was advised of this discussion paper and invited to make a written submission.

The ABA found that SCB had not demonstrated that there was a sufficient need for another community broadcasting service in Sydney for the Christian community, whose needs were being met to some extent by an existing fulltime Christian community broadcasting service, along with another 82 hours per week of Christian programming on other radio services across the Sydney licence area.

The ABA did not seek public submissions relating to the service proposed by SCB. Rather, it sought public submissions in relation to the ABA’s discussion paper on options for the future use of 1386 kHz for Sydney. Consequently, submissions received in relation to this discussion paper were focussed on the options for its future use.

SCB encouraged people to write to the ABA supporting its proposed service using the 1386 frequency. To date, ACMA has received 332 letters and 3 petitions in response to this campaign. It did not receive any submissions explicitly opposed to SCB’s service, however, the ABA did not seek submissions relating to specific proposed services.

Public submissions provided in relation to the ABA’s discussion paper on options for the future use of 1386 kHz for Sydney were made available for public perusal on the ABA’s website. The ABA did not seek public comment on these submissions. Two submitters requested that their submissions not be made available on the basis that they contained information that they considered was commercial-in-confidence. The ABA granted their request.

ACMA understands that Mr Murphy is referring to SCB’s application for a community broadcasting licence using 1386 kHz, which was submitted to the ABA in 2002. The ABA did not make a specific finding in relation to these figures. Rather, the ABA found that SCB had not demonstrated that there was a sufficient need for another community broadcasting service in Sydney for the Christian community, whose needs were being met to some extent by an existing fulltime Christian community broadcasting service, along with another 82 hours per week of Christian programming on other radio services across the Sydney licence area.

The ABA considered all of the information provided by SCB in its submissions. However, as stated in response to part (5), the ABA considered that the needs of the Christian community in Sydney were being met to some extent by the existing fulltime Christian community broadcasting service, along with another 82 hours per week of Christian programming available on other radio services across the Sydney licence area.

The ABA did not test the reliability of the research data submitted by SCB. The decision made by the ABA to not allocate the licence to SCB was based upon the amount of Christian programming currently available on existing services in the Sydney licence area. Please refer to part (5).

item.label: (a)
item.para: A variation to the Sydney licence area plan was determined by the ABA in March 2002 to make available an additional community broadcasting service using the 1386 kHz frequency. No further change has been made since that decision.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Due to concerns regarding the proximity of the Homebush Bay transmitter site to new residential areas, the ABA decided that the 1386 kHz frequency would not be used for any purpose until it had completed a review of options for its future use. It announced that decision in a news release issued on 26 March 2003.

item.label: (a)
item.para: The ABA’s General Manager, Mr Giles Tanner, gave a speech to the Association of Christian Broadcasters on 2 July 2004. He has not retained a copy of his speaking notes, however, his background briefing for that meeting included the information that the ABA had received 280 letters and 3 petitions of support for Rhema Sydney in relation to the ABA’s review of options for the future use of 1386 kHz in Sydney.

item.label: (b)
item.para: At that time, it had been the ABA’s intention to further consider the issue of 1386 kHz at its forthcoming Planning and Licensing Committee meeting to be held on 29 July 2004. Mr Tanner believes it was likely that he shared that information with attendees.

Commercial Radio Australia (CRA) requested that their submission on options for the future use of 1386 kHz remain commercial in confidence. After considering CRA’s reasons, the ABA granted their request. ACMA will consider all submissions received at the time that it makes a decision on the future use of the 1386 kHz frequency.

A decision on the future use of 1386 kHz will be made to ensure the best possible use of 1386 kHz, with consideration to the planning criteria at section 23 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. ACMA will consider the comments of all submitters when making its decision. The process has been open and transparent to date, with the release of a discussion paper, an advertisement placed in The Sydney Morning Herald on 10 May 2004 advising of the discussion paper and seeking public submissions, the publishing on the ABA website of the discussion paper and the publishing of non-confidential submissions that it received in response to the discussion paper.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 1 June 2005:

item.para: Did the Minister read the article ‘Coonan’s Salvage Challenge’ in The Australian on 31 May 2005.

In respect of the assertions in the report that, contrary to the public interest, past media legislative reforms have always been made to protect the interests of the big media moguls, will the Minister ensure that the redrafted Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002 will not permit further concentration of media ownership in Australia; if not, why not.

What is the Minister’s response to the view that the Government should allow free-to-air networks to offer multi-channelling services to consumers and will the Minister act to achieve this; if not, why not.

What is the Minister’s response to the view that the Government should act to allow a fourth free-to-air television network to be established in Australia and will the Minister act to achieve this; if not, why not.

What is the Minister’s response to the view that competition must be allowed to flourish in the media rather than being stifled by the Government and can the Minister explain how the Government’s proposed media reforms will promote competition; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Yes.
As noted in answers to previous questions by the honourable member on this issue, the Government is currently considering its approach to media ownership reform.
This matter is one of a number currently under review and the Government will announce its decision at an appropriate time.
This matter is one of a number that have arisen in the context of the current digital television reviews. The Government will announce its decision on the reviews at an appropriate time.
The Government is currently considering its approach to media reform issues including those outlined above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 2 June 2005:

item.para: Further to the answer to question No. 898 (Hansard, 24 May 2005, page 90), is he aware of the complexity of the PKU diet and that the special medical foods used in the treatment of PKU are very unpalatable; if not, why not.
Is he aware of Australian studies that have shown that up to half of the patients with PKU may be responsive to BH4; if not, why not.
Is he aware that making BH4 available to BH4 responsive PKU patients could have a dramatic effect on their quality of life; if not, why not.

Apart from listing BH4 on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS), is he aware of any other strategies that could be employed to allow patients with PKU to gain affordable access to this innovative therapy; if so, what are they.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: I am aware that the recognised treatment for PKU is strict dietary management.

As advised in Question No 898 4 (a) I am aware that there has been some research undertaken in Australia to determine the efficacy of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4). These studies could potentially support a submission by the sponsor to apply for marketing approval for the product. The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) carries out a range of assessment and monitoring activities to ensure therapeutic goods available in Australia are of an acceptable standard with regards to quality, safety and efficacy. It is up to the sponsor company to provide the evidence (study results) to the TGA for assessment.
Without the necessary assessment by the TGA, the Government is not in a position to act on any alleged effects of BH4 on the quality of life of PKU patients.
The Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) is the main mechanism by which the Australian Government subsidises the cost of medicines including specialised nutrients for some patients.

As BH4 does not currently have TGA marketing approval, and has not been assessed by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, it cannot be subsidised under the PBS. In addition, if the product does not have TGA marketing approval it cannot be purchased by patients.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 14 June 2005:

item.para: For the year (a) 2000-2001, (b) 2001-2002, (c) 2002-2003, (d) 2003-2004, and (e) 2004-2005, how many airline passengers were granted clearance to enter Australia at the point of origin then refused entry to Australia on arrival.

In respect of airline passengers refused entry on arrival in Australia, on what basis does the Government require that the airline which carried the passenger has to meet the costs of returning the passenger and the detention costs incurred if return flights were unavailable on the date of arrival.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr John Cobb

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: While the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) does not keep this information in the format requested, the following table provides the number of persons refused immigration clearance at Australian Airports for the specified periods.

entry.para: Air Arrivals Refused Immigration Clearance at Australian Airports 2000-2001 to 2004-2005 to 30/4/05

item.para: In 2004-05, 1022 (62%) people were refused entry to Australia at airports after their visa had been cancelled as a result of an adverse bona-fides assessment.
Section 213 of the Migration Act 1958 places an obligation on carriers to meet the costs associated with the detention and removal of a non-citizen who is refused immigration clearance.
The obligation by the airline to cover these costs continues until the person is either released from immigration detention or is removed from Australia.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 14 June 2005:

item.para: Can he confirm that, for the purposes of Youth Allowance, young people are considered dependent on their parents until they are 25 years of age.

Can he confirm that child support liability for paying parents ceases when the child reaches 18 years of age except in the circumstances where the young person continues schooling for the remainder of that school year.
Can he explain the reasons for the difference between social security and child support legislation with respect to the age a young person is assumed to be independent.

Can he confirm that education costs have risen by an average of 7.7 per cent as measured by the Consumer Price Index (CPI) over 2004 compared with a general CPI increase of 2.4 per cent over the same period and that this has resulted in an increase in the financial burden on the families of young people in education.

Can he confirm that the child support liability of a paying parent ceases when the child reaches 18 years of age unless otherwise ordered by the Court; if so, will he propose amendments to the child support legislation to ensure paying parents continue payments in respect of young people over 18 years of age undertaking further education and, if he will not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: The Minister for Workforce Participation has advised that under Youth Allowance, all young people are considered to be dependent unless they meet independence criteria e.g. Unreasonable to Live at Home, has dependent child, self-supporting, turns 25 years of age, etc. If a young person does not meet one of these independence criteria they are considered to be dependent on their parents.

Maximum age provisions also determine whether a young person is qualified for Youth Allowance. These differ for young people who are studying full-time or those young people who are considered to be unemployed. The following maximum age provisions are set out in the Social Security Act 1991:
21 years for unemployed young people, OR
25 years for full-time students, OR
21 years and over, AND
is undertaking a course of education that is to last less than 12 months, AND
was on Newstart Allowance immediately before starting the course.

Full-time students retain qualification until the end of their course, even though this may occur after their 25th birthday. The young person must actually be undertaking the course as a full-time student and receiving Youth Allowance as they turn 25 in order to be assessed as not having attained the maximum age.
This means young unemployed people may qualify for Newstart Allowance and be treated as ‘independent’ from the age of 21.

Under child support legislation, child support obligations end when the child turns 18 years of age. Where a child is still attending full-time secondary school during the year they turn 18, an application may be made to extend the child support assessment to the last day of that school year.
The Minister for Workforce Participation and the Minister for Family and Community Services have advised that the difference relates to the purpose of the social security and child support systems.

The social security system provides a safety net of income support for specific groups of people, including young people from low income families who are seeking work or studying full time. A system of means testing is used as a key eligibility criterion for payment.

In relation to income support for young people, it is the Australian Government’s view that parents who have children claiming Youth Allowance should support their children, where they are able, until they reach financial independence. Financial independence is demonstrated through the young person’s work efforts and earnings over a reasonable period of time after they leave school.

The Child Support Scheme is based on the principle that parents have a legal parental responsibility to support their children even after separation. A child’s non-resident parent should continue to support the child until the child attains full legal capacity at the age of 18, or completes the year of secondary schooling during which the child turns 18. After that, a court, exercising jurisdiction under the Family Law Act 1975 may only make an order for maintenance if a young person remains financially dependent and is unable to support himself or herself because they are continuing their education or because of a disability.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) has advised that the Education Group of the Consumer Price Index (CPI) (which measures price changes in expenditures on preschools and primary, secondary, and tertiary education) rose 7.7 per cent through the year to December 2004 with the corresponding ALL groups CPI rising by 2.6 per cent (not 2.4 per cent as stated in the question).

The ABS advises that this is not the most recent CPI information available. From March quarter 2004 to March quarter 2005, the Education Group for the CPI rose 6.2 per cent with the corresponding ALL groups CPI rising by 2.4 per cent.
A parent’s liability under the Child Support Scheme ceases when the child turns 18, or on the last day of the full-time secondary year in which the child turns 18.

A court exercising jurisdiction under the Family Law Act 1975 can make an order for maintenance of a young person over 18 if satisfied that the order is necessary to enable the young person to complete his or her education or because of his or her physical or mental disability. These orders are made on a discretionary basis, taking into account the parents’ relative capacity to provide for the young person, and the young person’s capacity to provide for his or her own support.

The Ministerial Taskforce on Child Support recently completed a detailed review of the Child Support Scheme and has presented its report, In the Best Interests of Children, to Government. The report includes some recommendations relating to young people over 18. The Government will fully consider the report’s recommendations before responding.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 15 June 2005:

item.para: Since 1996-1997, what research and development work has been undertaken by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) relating to the operation and capabilities of the United States Defence Support Program satellites and the forthcoming Space Based InfraRed System (SBIRS).
What sum has been spent on this research and development work in each financial year since 1996-1997.
What further research and development work by the DSTO is planned to be conducted prior to and after SBIRS becomes operational and what is the projected cost of this work.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Since 1996-97, DSTO has assisted in maintaining Australian full knowledge and concurrence and in the assessment of SBIRS as a capability for detecting Australian targets of interest. To help sustain full knowledge and concurrence, DSTO developed a special purpose processor. This processor is able to accurately geo-locate and display Defence Support Program data on a background map and contains some DSTO-developed prototype target detection and tracking algorithms. With regard to other research and development work performed by DSTO in relation to the United States Defence Support Program and SBIRS, that program of work is classified.

The content and focus of DSTO’s research and development work would remain as outlined in part (1). On this basis, projected costs would be equivalent to approximately two staff years per year and in the order of $200,000 per year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 15 June 2005:

item.para: What steps has the Government taken, or is intending to take, to ensure appropriately qualified midwives who work in private practice are able to practise the full scope of their profession with adequate affordable insurance cover.

Will he explain why independent midwives are being excluded from current discussions between the Government and doctors as other maternity care providers concerning interim measures to ensure indemnity insurance cover.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The Australian Government is aware that independent midwives have been experiencing difficulty obtaining professional indemnity insurance. However, the Government has no powers to compel insurers to provide cover for independent midwives who are not employed by hospitals.

There are no current discussions taking place between the Government and any health practitioners regarding interim measures to ensure indemnity cover. While the Government is assisting doctors with the costs of their insurance through the Premium Support Scheme – in the context of ensuring the provision of services under Medicare – it is not providing insurance to any professional group.

The issue faced by doctors (including obstetricians) is different to that faced by midwives. For doctors the issue of indemnity insurance has been one of affordability, while for midwives, it is one of availability.

The Government does not believe it is appropriate to set itself up as an insurer to cover independent midwives – or psychologists, or dentists, or physiotherapists, or any of the other health professionals who are not covered by Medicare – just as it is not appropriate for the Government to enter the market as an insurer for doctors.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 16 June 2005:

item.para: What are the terms of reference for the review of the Therapeutic Goods Administration being conducted by Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu.
When will the review be (a) completed and (b) made public.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The terms of reference for the review of the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), conducted by Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, were as follows:
Review the recommendations of the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) report No.18 and the status of TGA initiatives in progress / completed in accordance with the ANAO report.
Assess recent regulatory actions to enforce compliance to draw lessons for the future that will assist TGA decision making affecting public health and safety.
Develop broader recommendations to the TGA on issues such as governance, procedural improvement, risk management and performance management.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: The review will be completed by 29 July 2005. (b) A summary of the report will be made available after it has been received by the department.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 21 June 2005:

item.para: Can he confirm that the Australian Episcopal Conference of the Catholic Church (AECCC) has received funding for the provision of family planning programs; if so, (a) what sum did it receive for this purpose, and (b) what proportion of the total funding available for family planning does the sum it received represent.
What is the name and address of each organisation that received funding for the provision of family planning programs and what sum did it receive.
What is the nature of the family planning programs provided by the AECCC and do these programs promote family planning techniques that include contraception.

Can he guarantee that individuals requesting advice on contraception and abortion will have access to advice provided in an objective and value-free manner through the programs provided by the AECCC; if not, can he explain why he approved funding for the AECCC to provide family planning programs.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes, the Australian Episcopal Conference of the Roman Catholic Church (AECRCC) has been funded since 1990 to provide natural family planning services across Australia. These funds were previously provided to the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission, with funding commencing in 1974.

item.label: (a)
item.para: In 2004-05 funding for the Australian Episcopal Conference of the Roman Catholic Church was $918,826; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: This is in the order of 5.5% of the overall funding for Family Planning.
In 2004-05 four national bodies were funded directly by the Australian Government to provide Family Planning services.

entry.para: Australian Episcopal Conference of the Roman Catholic Church
Australian Federation of Pregnancy Support Services
Australian Federation of Pregnancy Support Services

item.para: The Australian Government decided on 29 March 2004 that funding for all state and territory based family planning organisations would be incorporated within the Population Health Outcome Funding Agreements (PHOFAs) for the period 2004-05 to 2008-09. The level of funding allocated by the state or territory government for this purpose generally cannot be disaggregated, however, funding provided to support family planning organisations by states and territories is expected to be at levels similar to the previous year.
In 2003-04, the following funding was provided by the Australian Government to state and territory family planning organisations:

The South Australian and the Australian Capital Territory governments have received funding for family planning via the PHOFAs for some years. The level of funding allocated by SA and the ACT for this purpose can not be disaggregated.

(3) The AECRCC is funded to provide natural family planning counselling for the purpose of achieving or avoiding pregnancy, which includes the provision of information regarding methods for avoiding conception based on a woman’s natural fertility cycle. Other activities include vocational training and education to health and other professionals as well as sexual and reproductive health and education services to high need population groups, such as older women in their reproductive health years, young people, regional and rural Australians, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and people with a disability.
(4) The AECRCC is funded to provide natural family planning counselling for the purpose of achieving or avoiding pregnancy, it is not funded to undertake unplanned pregnancy counselling.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 18 July 2005:

item.para: Is he aware that cochlear implants and their associated hardware are provided free of charge to people under 21 years and over 65 years of age.
Is he aware that the Commonwealth provides free maintenance for cochlear implants and their associated hardware.
Can he explain why the Commonwealth provides upgrades on cochlear implants for people under 21 years of age free of any charge but does not provide upgrades for people over 65 years of age.
Is he aware the Commonwealth provides upgrades of hearing aids.
Will he act to provide upgrades to all people with cochlear implants; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as folows:

item.para: At the time of implantation, the Australian Government Hearing Services Program does not make any contribution to the cost of the cochlear implants or the associated hardware. Some people may be able to access cochlear implants and the hardware free-of-charge through Cochlear Implant Centres, state and territory government schemes, private health insurance or the Department of Veterans’ Affairs.

Speech processors provided for children and young adults under the age of 21 years, who have cochlear implants are maintained through the Australian Government Hearing Services Program. Speech processors are separate devices, worn externally, which enable cochlear implants to operate.

The Australian Government Hearing Services Program specifically targets children and young adults under 21 years of age who have cochlear implants because of the critical nature of profound hearing loss during childhood and early adulthood. Hearing loss amongst children is particularly critical for spoken language development, with a lack of access to the spoken language compounding difficulties which the child is likely to experience in learning to talk, understand speech and participate in his/her family’s social environment and the broader community.
Supporting the continued access of young adults to cochlear speech processors assists these profoundly deaf individuals to continue their education and maintain family and social relationships.

The development of profound deafness in individuals aged 65 years and over does not, in general, confer the same level of risks in language and social development as the occurrence of profound deafness in children and young adults.
The Australian Government Hearing Services Program funds the provision of replacement and upgraded speech processors for profoundly deaf children and young adults under the age of 21 years.

The Government has substantially increased the level of funding available to improve children’s access to cochlear implant speech processors. As part of its 2004 Budget, it announced the allocation of an additional $7.6 million over four years to fund replacement and upgraded speech processors for children and young adults fitted with cochlear implants. This equates to 330 additional replacements/upgrades during 2004-05, and up to 230 additional upgrades/replacements in each subsequent year.

The Government will continue to identify and investigate issues on the national provision of hearing services under the Australian Government Hearing Services Program. The identification of emerging demand for hearing services, including access to cochlear implant speech processor upgrades, will be considered along with other issues facing the program.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 22 June 2005:

item.para: Has he read the article titled ‘Nations surface to boost whaling bid’ in The Sydney Morning Herald on 20 June 2005, which reported that “Japan’s whaling ambitions are set to march forward today as a clutch of new member countries joins the International Whaling Commission”.
Will the Government enforce Australian law and stop the illegal slaughter of whales in Australian waters; if so, when, if not, why not.
Will the Government take Japan to the International Court of Justice to permanently end the slaughter of whales; if so, when; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: I cannot recall reading the article.

Yes. In the Exclusive Economic Zone off the Australian Antarctic Territory (AAT) this would be subject to consideration of enforcement capability and the non-universal recognition of Australian sovereignty over the AAT.
The government has not decided to pursue legal action in the ICJ at this stage, but has not ruled out this option.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: How are the Australian Non-Government Organisations (NGOs) chosen for the AusAID-NGO Cooperation Program (ANCP).
What is the application process.
How much funding do the NGO’s in ANCP receive.
What activities are (a) subsidised and (b) not subsidised in the ANCP.
How many countries participated in the ANCP in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998 (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001, (g) 2002, (h) 2003, (i) 2004, and (j) 2005.
How many NGO’s worked in each country under the ANCP in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998 (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001, (g) 2002, (h) 2003, (i) 2004, and (j) 2005.
Do the NGOs in the ANCP provide evidence of their expenditures of the money they receive; if so, how is this presented.
Do the NGOs in the ANCP provide progress reports or feedback about their programs; if so, how is it presented and how often is it presented.

Are independent assessments made of the work that the NGOs in the ANCP undertake in the different countries; if so, what is the process involved in this; if not, how is the progress of the NGO’s work assessed.
Which countries have NGO Cooperation Agreements with Australia.
Under what criteria are the countries with NGO Cooperation Agreements chosen.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Non-Government Organisations (NGOs) based in Australia self nominate for accreditation under the AusAID accreditation program. All NGOs accredited by AusAID are eligible for funding under the AusAID – NGO Cooperation Program (ANCP).

NGOs self nominate for accreditation which is a prerequisite for funding under the ANCP. AusAID’s accreditation process aims to provide AusAID and the Australian public, with confidence that the Australian Government is funding professional, well managed, community based organisations that are capable of delivering quality development outcomes. Considered internationally as best practice, its purpose is to check the NGO’s structure, financial and management systems, philosophy, links to the Australian community and capacity to conduct quality development work.
In financial year 2005-2006 the financial allocation for ANCP is $27.0 million.
Activities that are, and are not, supported under the ANCP are articulated in section 3 of AusAID’s NGO Cooperation Program (ANCP) Generic Guidelines at Attachment 1.

AusAID regularly publishes annual statistics on NGO activities on our website. Information relevant to questions (a) – (h) are published on the sector of the site dedicated to Non-Government Organisations (NGOs) at www.ausaid.gov.au/ngos/annual.cfm. In financial year 2004-2005 forty six (46) NGOs participated in ANCP. Data is not yet available on the numbers of NGO’s that will participate in ANCP in 2005-2006.

AusAID’s regularly published annual statistics on NGO activities at www.ausaid.gov.au/ngos/ annual.cfm contains information relevant to questions (a) – (h). While final reporting has yet to be received for financial year 2004-2005, AusAID anticipates that 56 countries will have participated in the ANCP in financial year 2004-2005. Data is not yet available on the numbers of countries that will participate in ANCP in 2005-2006.

AusAID’s regularly published annual statistics on NGO activities at www.ausaid.gov.au/ ngos/annual.cfm contains information relevant to questions (a) – (h). While final reporting has yet to be received for financial year 2004-2005, AusAID expectation, regarding how many NGOs worked in each country under the ANCP, is at Attachment 2. Data is not yet available on how many NGOs will work in each country under the ANCP in 2005-2006 as the application process is currently underway.

Accredited NGOs are required to submit to AusAID a financial acquittal for ANCP funds on 1 October of the financial year following the financial year in which the funds were provided. In addition, NGOs must annually provide a copy of their audited financial statements to AusAID on, or before, 1 April. (ie copy of audited financial statement received 1 April 2004, ANCP funding received for period July 2004-June 2005, financial acquittal received 1 October 2005).

Recipients of ANCP funding are required to provide to AusAID on, or before, 1 April of the financial year in which the ANCP funds are provided, a performance rating on the achievement of objectives for the ANCP activities of that financial year. Detail on the ratings and how they are to be applied can be found in appendix 4 of the NGO Package of Information on AusAID’s web site. In addition, on 1 October of the financial year following the financial year in which ANCP funds were provided, accredited NGOs that received ANCP funds must provide AusAID with an ANCP Annual Development Plan Report. The format for this report can be found at Attachment 3 and on AusAID’s website.

AusAID is in the process of developing improved mechanisms for measuring - a) the effectiveness of the AusAID NGO Cooperation Program (ANCP) as a whole, b) the effectiveness of individual agencies within the ANCP, and c) the effectiveness of individual projects. In the interim, a cluster evaluation of NGO ANCP activities in Cambodia is currently underway. This will facilitate assessment of the extent to which NGO activities funded through ANCP are achieving their stated objectives and contributing to the aims of the ANCP. The cluster evaluation will also enable AusAID to compare findings with NGO’s self-assessment of project activities that is reported in their annual reports.

The following countries have individual NGO Cooperation Agreements with Australia: Solomon Islands, PNG, Palestinian Territories, Vietnam and Cambodia. Through the regionally focused Australian Partnerships with African Communities program, the following countries also receive assistance: South Africa; Mozambique; Malawi; Zambia; Zimbabwe, Kenya and Uganda.

There are no set criteria for selecting countries for NGO Cooperation Agreements. In determining the best delivery mechanism for development assistance, individual AusAID Country Program areas may consider engaging with civil society as an effective approach. If Country Program areas decide to work with NGOs AusAID Cooperation Agreements are one way of facilitating that engagement.

quote.para: Attachment 1
AUSAID NGO COOPERATION PROGRAM (ANCP) GENERIC GUIDELINES
3. DEVELOPMENT APPROACH
3.1 Agencies should have a proven track record of activity in the sector and/or country concerned, and demonstrated links with an effective and accountable in-country implementing partner.
3.2 To be eligible for funding, activities must:

item.para: have a strategy to ensure the development outcomes will be sustainable by the end of the activity;

where possible, use existing community structures, be implemented by local or Australian NGOs acceptable to the national or local authorities of the country in which the activities are planned, and be consistent with the country’s development policies;
provide channels for Australians to contribute directly and meaningfully in international development efforts through voluntary activities and financial support;

encourage and facilitate community self help and self reliance through local participation in defining goals, formulating development strategies, contributing to costs (including contributions in-kind), and in the implementation and management of such activities;

ensure that the specific social and economic needs of both men and women are addressed and that opportunities for women to participate as decision makers in determining objectives and types of activities are increased;
provide good value for money;
use successful conventional or innovative approaches to problem solving which have potential for wider application in other communities;
strengthen counterpart organisations in developing countries so as to enable them to sustain activities after Australian assistance has ceased;
benefit groups selected on the basis of need - not on religious, sectarian or political grounds;
encourage sound environmental and ecological practices; and
encourage good governance and respect for human rights.

quote.para: 3.3 Prior approval from AusAID is required for:

item.para: all activities in Aceh, Maluku and Papua. NGOs are required to submit documentation showing that the activity has the approval, at least at Provincial Government level, of the relevant Indonesian Government authorities;
all activities in the areas of labour unions institution capacity building, training and advice; labour law and workers’ rights;

quote.para: (NB Activities requiring prior approval should be submitted 8 weeks before ADPlans and base agency proposals are due to avoid any delays in the normal ANCP approval process.)
3.4 Approval will not be provided for activities which:

item.para: Are determined reasonably to be contrary to the interests of the Commonwealth of Australia;
subsidise evangelism or missionary outreach;
support activities by partisan political organisations;
support independence movements;

provide direct assistance to unions to organise industrial action and give direct material assistance to striking workers (while not precluding activities in the areas of labour unions institution capacity building, training and advice; labour law and workers’ rights that are subject to prior approval (See 3.3));

involve welfare activities (welfare is defined as care and maintenance, other than in refugee and emergency situations, which aims to maintain people in a particular condition on a longer-term basis. Substantial and broad impact on social and economic conditions in the community is not normally expected from welfare programs. Welfare is typically provided on an individual or family basis including home-based and institutional care programs, such as those provided by orphanages, homes for the elderly, hospices, support to the disabled, and the provision of food for those who are destitute);
have a significant component of professional salaries at Australian or ‘expatriate’ rates;
are for emergency relief activities;
are for development education;
are for recurrent costs - unless there is a convincing plan to ensure the recipients will be able to take over those recurrent costs within the life of the activity;

are currently funded under other Australian Government programs - NGOs seeking AusAID funds must declare all other proposals or sources of Australian Government funding which may impact on the activity;
involve retrospective funding;
do not comply with the guidelines set out in Australia’s Assistance for Family Planning Activities;
are primarily research focused;
are focused primarily on the provision of equipment, freight or buildings unless:
the equipment, freight or buildings to be supplied are clearly part of a broader development program;
the equipment, freight or buildings to be supplied are appropriate to the environment in which they are to be placed;
the recipients have the capacity to maintain the equipment or buildings concerned and to meet recurrent costs;
the NGO has established that effective quality control measures have been used in the selection of goods for freighting overseas; and
adequate planning has gone into the goods’ use and distribution so as to establish their part in the overall value of the activity.

quote.para: 3.5 Activities require a strategy to promote the Australian identity of the activity in an appropriate manner.
Attachment 2

entry.para: NGOs in Individual Countries in ANCP

ANCP Annual Development Plan Report

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: What sum is allocated to each of the activities undertaken in the community engagement and development education program which are run though AusAID.
Which activity in the community engagement and development education program receives (a) the most funding and (b) the least funding.
How are the activities selected for the community engagement and development education program.
Is the global education program for Australian primary and secondary teachers still operating; if so, how many teachers are being supported by this program.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The total community engagement and development education program budget for 2005/06 $3.0 million and is broken down as follows: global education $915,000; internet and photo library $185,000; media and media monitoring $405,000; community engagement $1,095,000; Focus magazine $250,000; publication distribution $150,000.

Within this breakdown, community engagement activities in general receive the greatest funding. Within community engagement in 2005/06, a joint publication with Lonely Planet will get the most funding, $200,000. The least funding for a program, $45,000, will be given to maintenance of the photo library.

Activities for the community engagement and development education program are selected based on their ability to achieve the objectives of AusAID’s Public Affairs Strategy 2005-2007 in a cost effective manner.

Yes. In 2004/05 over 15,000 primary and secondary teachers and pre-service teachers received professional development training. Over 30,000 curriculum materials were distributed to Australian teachers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Can he account for the increase of aid funding to Afghanistan from $19.7 to $26 million.
Which programs received increased funding.
Were any new programs introduced; if so, what were they.
Do official authorities or government departments receive aid in Afghanistan; if so,

item.label: (a)
item.para: which ones,

item.label: (b)
item.para: for what purpose, and

item.label: (c)
item.para: what accountability mechanisms are in place to establish that the funds are used appropriately.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The increase in aid funding to Afghanistan is due to the increase in Other Government Department (OGD) estimates from $1.2 million in 2004-05 to $7.5 million in 2005-06.
Other Government Department (estimates).
The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) will be undertaking a project to provide housing for returnees. The project will commence in 2005-06.
Yes

item.label: (a)
item.para: Ministries of Interior (MoI) and Foreign Affairs (MoFA)

item.label: (b)
item.para: Provision of technical assistance to improve border control and passport and visa issuing systems.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The accountability mechanisms are:

Project Steering Committee, comprised of representatives from AusAID, DIMIA, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and the Afghan Ambassador to Australia. The committee allocates funding for the activity and ensures that project activities accord with objectives. The committee provides reporting on the activity every three months.

Counterpart steering committee in Kabul, comprised of representatives from the Afghan MoI, MoFA and other Afghan stakeholders such as Kabul Airport and Border Police. The Committee oversees the project in Afghanistan.
Ongoing frequent working-level communication between DIMIA and the Afghan Government (through the Afghan Embassy in Canberra, MOI and MoFA).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: What programs exist to combat Avian Influenza, and what sum does each program receive.
In which countries do these programs operate.
Who administers the programs.
Which country receives the most funding from the Australian Government to combat Avian Influenza.
How many Australians are employed in these programs.
Are local people employed to work in the programs.
How many people are affected by Avian Influenza and in which countries do they reside.
How many people have died from Avian Influenza and where were they from.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Since April 2003, the Australian Government, through the aid program, has approved 17 separate initiatives targeting Avian Influenza and other communicable diseases such as SARS. The approved activities have a combined value of $18.2 million. Please refer to Table 1 for a description of each approved activity.
Please refer to Table 1.
Please refer to Table 1.

Of the $18.2 million committed through the aid program to date, $12.8 million has been directed toward international organisations and regional bodies such as the WHO and the ASEAN Secretariat for use in cooperative and non-country specific or regional responses. However, of the $5.4 million approved for bilateral or country specific initiatives, most (some $4.3 million) has been directed toward Indonesia.

It is not practicable to provide a precise figure for the number of Australian personnel employed on these programs because of the diverse nature and disparate timing of the various Australian funded bilateral and multilateral initiatives. However, under the programs outlined in Table 1, the Australian Government, through DoHA, will directly engage three Australian epidemiologists to undertake program activities. Australian personnel at the CSIRO Animal Health Laboratories in Geelong are also providing assistance to visiting personnel from some affected countries. In addition, a significant proportion of Australian funding has been provided to international organisations and regional bodies such as the WHO and the ASEAN Secretariat. These organisations utilise that funding to access personnel and resources from a range of countries, including Australia.

Yes, where possible local personnel are employed on the programs. Local personnel are also the focus of capacity building activities for affected countries. For example, the CSIRO Animal Health Laboratories in Geelong have provided epidemiological and diagnostic training for personnel from affected developing countries.

According to the WHO’s most recent reporting there have been 109 laboratory confirmed cases of Avian Influenza in humans since December 2003. Vietnam has the largest number of confirmed cases to date with 87 in total. A further17 cases have been confirmed in Thailand and 4 in Cambodia. There are also as yet unconfirmed reports of a further 15 cases around the region, including a further 2 fatalities in Indonesia.

The WHO reports 55 laboratory confirmed human deaths resulting from Avian Influenza since December 2003, 38 of which occurred in Vietnam, 12 in Thailand, 4 in Cambodia and 1 in Indonesia. There have also been unconfirmed reports of a further 2 fatalities in Indonesia during July 2005.

quote.para: Table 1. AusAID assistance to combat Avian Influenza and other emerging and resurging zoonotic diseases – total commitments since 2003 $18.2 million

entry.para: World Health Organisation: Western Pacific Regional Office

WHO: capacity building to help prevent and control outbreaks of SARS in the Western Pacific region, including provision of additional research expertise as well as the procurement of medical equipment unavailable in China.
A further $500,000 was provided for SARS prevention and control in China through existing bilateral rural health projects.
WHO Geneva: strengthening the operations of the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network.

WHO Western Pacific Regional Office: employing experts in epidemiology, animal health, virology, laboratory and public health to address Avian Influenza outbreaks as well as to procure supplies and equipment and to produce training materials.
WHO South East Asia Regional Office:

WHO South East Asia Regional Office: enabling technical support and the provision of essential supplies to address Avian Influenza, particularly diagnostic kits and personnel protective equipment for East Timor, Thailand and Burma.
DAFF, CSIRO Animal Health Laboratory Geelong
DAFF, CSIRO Animal Health Laboratory Geelong: responding to the epidemiological and diagnostic needs arising from the Avian Influenza outbreak.
WHO Indonesia office: providing epidemiological and other technical assistance, including antiviral supplies and training.
WHO Indonesia office: strengthening Indonesia’s surveillance and response capacities for diseases such as Avian Influenza.
ASEAN Secretariat: helping to build capacity to deal with infectious disease outbreaks through the ASEAN-Australia Development Cooperation Program.
WHO Cambodia: strengthening Cambodia’s surveillance and response capacities for Avian Influenza.
WHO WPRO, ASEAN Secretariat, DAFF: strengthening the regions ability to identify and respond to outbreaks of emerging and resurging zoonotic diseases.
Indonesia, East Timor and South Pacific

DAFF: providing workshops and training to promote sharing of information, lessons, and advice to help facilitate more efficient and effective responses to Avian Influenza for Indonesia, East Timor and South Pacific participants.
WHO Geneva: strengthening WHO’s Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network and Global Influenza Program
DoHA: establishing and managing a regional network of Australian epidemiologists based in Indonesia, Vietnam and China.

WHO Indonesia: assisting the Indonesian Government to set up rapid response and surveillance teams, to ensure hospitals are ready with trained personnel and equipment and to improve the capacity of both human and veterinary laboratories.
WHO China: strengthening preparedness for potential influenza pandemics and to develop early warning and response capacity to deal with emerging public health threats.
DPRK : $250,000 each to WHO and FAO to help DPRK respond to Avian Influenza

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Can the Minister outline how the aid funding allocated to China is divided up.
Will there be any new aid initiatives in the area of (a) governance, (b) health, and (c) environment for China; if so, what are they and what sum will they receive.
Do any of the initiatives include Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs); if so, (a) how many, (b) what are their names, and (c) what roles do they play.

Do government departments or officials receive funding through Australia’s aid program; if so, which departments or officials receive funding and what is the breakdown of how they allocate their funding.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The estimated budget for bilateral development cooperation with China in 2005-06 is $38 million. Estimated sectoral expenditure in 2005-06 is as follows:
Governance: approximately 25 per cent of the program, or $9.5 million;
Health: approximately 35 per cent of the program, or $13.3 million;
Environment: approximately 30 per cent of the program, or $11.4 million;
Other activities: approximately 10 per cent of the program, or $3.8 million.

The Chinese and Australian governments expect to finalise a new country program strategy in August-September 2005. This country program strategy will provide a framework for Australian development cooperation with China from 2006 through to 2010. New aid initiatives will be developed under the three key themes of the strategy, namely governance, health and environment. Details of these new initiatives are still being worked out.

Since 1997, the aid program has funded a “Human Rights Technical Cooperation Program” (HRTC), through which Australia assists China in the promotion, protection and administration of human rights. The HRTC complements and supports the annual Human Rights Dialogue between Australia and China. Some HRTC activities have involved Chinese non-governmental organisations.

item.label: (a)
item.para: As of June 2005, three NGOs have been involved in the HRTC.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The following NGOs have been involved in the HRTC: (i) the United Nations Association of China; (ii) the Foundation for Human Rights Development; and (iii) the All-China Women’s Federation.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The HRTC provided technical assistance to the United Nations Association of China to implement a “Model UN Commission on Human Rights” in November 2004. This activity helped educate approximately 200 Chinese students on human rights issues.

The Foundation of Human Rights Development is working with the Chinese Ministry of Civil Affairs in the development of democratic management skills within community committees and the delivery of community services. Under the HRTC, a group from the Foundation for Human Rights Development will visit Australia in August 2005 to study Australian approaches in this area and prepare a training program for implementation under subsequent years of the HRTC.

The All-China Women’s Federation (ACWF) is an umbrella organisation under the sponsorship of the government. The aim of the ACWF is to “represent and safeguard women’s rights and interests and promote equality between women and men”. Ten HRTC activities have been implemented in collaboration with the ACWF. These activities have supported the ACWF’s efforts to address domestic violence in China, and combat trafficking in women and children.

The Australian aid program generally does not provide funding directly to partner country government departments or officials. Aid funding is channelled through Australian Managing Contractors or through multilateral organisations, including United Nations organisations and the multilateral development banks.
In the China program, there are two exceptions to this general rule.

Firstly, the aid program funds a number of scholarships, which enable Chinese officials to study in Australia for 18 months. In 2005-06, 24 such scholarships will be offered. The scholarship entitlement includes a stipend paid to the Chinese officials (currently $18,360 per annum for unaccompanied officials or $25,520 per annum for accompanied officials) plus an establishment allowance (currently $2,193) paid to the Chinese officials at the beginning of the scholarship.

Secondly, the aid program through a “Small Activities Scheme” funds a number of grass-roots development activities in China. Funding for this scheme amounts to $1 million per financial year. On average, approximately 20 activities are implemented each year through the scheme. The funding is provided through local offices of the Chinese Ministry of Commerce to Chinese recipient agencies.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: Can he confirm that there will be an increase of $56.6 million to the aid budget for Papua New Guinea this year.
What areas or initiatives will this additional funding be used for.
Have any new programs been initiated; if so, what are they
Have any programs been eliminated from the aid budget this year; if so, which ones, and why.
Have any programs received less funding than last year; if so, which ones, and why.
How many Non-Governmental Organisations receive funding in Papua New Guinea for aid-related projects.
Which government departments or authorities in Papua New Guinea receive funding from the Australian Government and what do they use it for.
What mechanisms are in place to establish that funds are used for the intended purpose.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: At the release of the 2005-06 budget, we estimated an increase in ODA funding to PNG of $56.6 million. This was associated with an estimated increase in AFP expenditure in PNG under the Enhanced Cooperation Program (ECP). On 13 May 2005, the PNG Supreme Court ruled that several aspects of the ECP Act failed to comply with the PNG Constitution. The Governments of Australia and PNG are still in discussion about how to resolve these legal issues. In the meantime AFP personnel have been withdrawn from PNG. It is unclear what impact this will have on the estimated budget outcome for 2005-06.
The estimated additional funding is to be used for the ECP – see answer above.
Yes. New activities expected to commence in 2005-06 are:

entry.para: Mechanism to provide short term assistance to the PNG National Department of Health
Assistance to institutions providing pre-service training for the health sector
New program to support PNG’s HIV/AIDS response
Program to replace and/or rehabilitate substandard bridges on national key roads in nine Provinces
Development of training workshops for public servants on core competencies for effective public administration
Facility to select and manage assistance to PNG for public sector reform activities
Implementation of new Civil Society program
PNG Agricultural Research and Development Support Program
Program to improve the ability of PNG agricultural research institutions to undertake high quality research benefiting smallholder farmers

item.para: The following aid activities to PNG were finalised in 2004-05 and therefore won’t receive funding in 2005-06:
Women’s and Children’s Health Project
Medical Equipment Management Project
Immigration Strengthening Project
National Fisheries College Strengthening Project
Bougainville Cocoa Rehabilitation Project
Bougainville Ex-Combatants Trust Fund
Bougainville Support for Peace Process
Bougainville Program Management Project
National Roads and Bridges Maintenance Project Phase 1
PNG Silver Jubilee Sports Program
Upgrading Provincial High Schools II
Quality Initiatives in PNG Education
Support to the World Bank Consultant Trust Fund
Advisory Support Facility Phase 1
Correctional Services Phase 2

Funding for aid activities varies from year to year, depending on the stage of the activity and planned outputs for that financial year. For example, funding for the Bougainville Coastal Trunk Road Maintenance project has been as follows:

entry.para: The project commenced in April 2002 with initial expenditure related to the start up planning phase leading towards the implementation of works.
Increase in funding as the project is fully implemented and maintaining the Bougainville Coastal Trunk Road.
Increase in funding as the road works are extended to the North West Coast Road and Buka Ring Road.

Decrease in funding as the project is expected to end in April 2005. No new road works are commenced and the focus is on completion of works and transfer of skills and knowledge through training courses for the Bougainville Division of Technical Services (DTS), private contractors and communities who tender for labour intensive works.
Increase in funding as the project is extended for 12 months while a new program is designed. The project will focus on maintaining the improved road assets to date.

item.para: In 2004-05, 130 non-government organisations received funding in Papua New Guinea for aid-related projects.

The Australian aid program does not provide direct funding to PNG Government Departments. Several PNG departments do receive technical assistance and capacity building support to help strengthen their performance eg, the National Departments of Health, Treasury, Education and the Department of Works (who are responsible for infrastructure maintenance). Through AusAID, the Australian Government also provides funding to support key services in PNG, such as basic health, education and infrastructure maintenance. This funding is provided through commercial Managing Contractors to ensure the funding is used for its intended purpose.

AusAID has accountability systems and controls in place to ensure funds are used for their intended purpose. All AusAID programs are designed to manage risks such as fraud and corruption. Risk and Fraud Management Plans are in place at every AusAID diplomatic post delivering and overseeing aid programs. These plans are updated at least annually.

A regular program of audits of all major commercial contractors and Australian Non-Government Organisations (NGOs) is conducted to ensure they comply with financial, contractual and activity management controls. Implementing partners, including commercial Managing Contractors, are carefully selected by means of contestable and transparent public tendering.

Where funds are provided through Australian NGOs there is a rigorous accreditation process required to qualify for AusAID funding. Where funds are provided through local NGOs there is also a rigorous system in place to check bona fides and appraise the objectives and design of the proposed activity.

AusAID programs focus on technical cooperation and capacity building activities rather than providing cash grants. At the level of individual aid activities, corruption risks are identified via a risk assessment developed during the design of activities. The implementing organisation is expected to apply and update the risk matrix throughout the life of the activity. Regular monitoring, review and spot checks are conducted as well as specific independent audits of financial management and performance at intermittent periods during the activity.

AusAID requires all instances of fraud or alleged fraud, either in Australia or overseas, to be reported to AusAID’s Audit Section. If an initial investigation by AusAID indicates a case of fraud against the Commonwealth, legal action will be taken to recover funds and to punish those responsible. Where the alleged fraud occurs overseas, it will be reported to local authorities for criminal proceedings to be instigated. AusAID reports allegations of fraud to the Attorney-General’s Department annually.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 23 June 2005:

item.para: What is the standard process for the appointment of a Head of Mission (HOM).
What role does the (a) Minister and (b) Prime Minister play in this appointment process.
Does the Minister or Prime Minister formally or informally advise the Department’s Corporate Management Division of their preferences.
Are all HOM positions advertised internally; if not, which positions are not filled through an advertised application process and how are these Heads of Mission chosen.
What is the maximum length of time that a mission has been headed by an acting HOM during the handover period from one officially appointed HOM to another.
How many Australian missions are currently managed by an acting HOM.
How long before a Head of Mission is due to depart a post is the position advertised internally.
Was this timeframe and the standard procedure followed for the recent appointment of the (a) High Commissioner to Singapore, (b) Ambassador to the United Arab Emirates, and (c) Ambassador to Burma.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: to (4) The same processes are in place today as were in place during the Hawke and Keating Governments.
Five months
One.
This can vary according to operational requirements.
Yes.
